-Diagonal lines in the portrait: Unlike horizontal lines, which suggest rest and repose, the use of the numerous diagonal lines creates an underlying sense of action, dynamism and tension. They help express the active nature and achievements of DeFazio's life in public service.
-The lapel pin: With each new Congress a new identification pin is issued; only 435 are made—one for each member of the House.
The bridge was scheduled for demolition in the late '90s. DeFazio intervened and secured millions in funding to repair the bridge which was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 2005.
-The wall photo is of the Isaac Lee Patterson Bridge over the Rogue River in Oregon. Designed and built in '31, it was designated a National Historic Civil Engineering Landmark in '82.

-The book the gavel rests upon is the Final Committee Report on the Design, Development, and Certification of the Boeing 737 Max, an investigation which
Chair DeFazio led.

Symbolism of the portrait includes:
 -The antique desk represents the history, tradition, and structure of our Congress.                                -The gavel represents DeFazio's chairmanship of the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee.
When I first entered Congress, I never envisioned that my career would span 36 years and culminate with my portrait being hung in this powerful space. I am truly humbled by this moment.

I am honored to unveil my portrait that will hang in the U.S. Capitol in the Transportation & Infrastructure Committee’s Hearing Room, painted by renowned Oregon artist Lynda Lanker. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FXlHCx6XwAId4uS.jpg
